716644f-a.text:
Bedford Street, southwest side, from Morton (originally Ardens) Street to Commerce Street, from Seventh Avenue South. The pavement in the foreground is exactly on the site of the Bedford Street Methodist Church, which was demolished when Seventh Avenue South was cut
through in 1915.
March 29, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
MgAtyc 3821
L

721733f-a.text:
Morton Street, east from Seventh Ave. EEtension to Bleecker Street. Building shown with sign, is No. 13 Morton Street and also fronts on Seventh
Ave.
March 24, 1933.
i. Sperr.  P.

709620f-a.text:
Seventh Avenue South, west side, south of Morton Street.
March 29th, 1933.
P.L. Sperr,Photographers.
The New York Times of March 12, 1940 reports the lease of site known as 62-4 Leroy Street and 16-18 Seventh Avenue South to a firm of builders to be improved with a 6 story apartment house for Fall occupancy. This plot has frontages of 50.4 feet on the former and 77.4 on the latter. A partial view o8 same appears here. It is the triangular corner (S.W.) distinguished by the tenement with the sign I Will Share". The structure bearing this legend is to be included in conjunction with the Sinclair gas station
709620f-a.folder: 7th Avenue South & Morton Street, Manhattan, NY

709621f-a.text:
Seventh Avenue South, at N.E. corner of Morton Street. Note poster for unemployment relief, shortly before Federal
Government assumed relief burden.
February 18, 1933.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.
709621f-a.folder: 7th Avenue South & Morton Street, Manhattan, NY

716645f-a.text:
Bedford Street, east side, south from and including Morton Street, showing across the vacant lot at the N.E. corner (former No. 60-62), the Bedford M.E. Church at the S.E. corner. This was demolished when Seventh Ave. was cut through and would today (1937) would be in the center of Seventh Ave. where Morton and Bedford Streets intersect. Buildings on the left are Nos. 64 and 66 Bedford Street, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Morton Street and are frame houses with brick fronts. They stand today
and adjoining a 6-story apartment house at the corner.
1914.
716645f-a.folder: Bedford Street & Morton Street, Manhattan, NY

716646f-a.text:
Bedford Street, northeast side, north from Morton Street (the eastern part, originally Ardens Street). Nos. 64-70, the four old houses in the middle of the first block, are frame buildings faced with
brick.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 359.
716646f-a.folder: Bedford Street & Morton Street, Manhattan, NY

721734f-b.text:
(1)
Junk shop in an old house at lo Morton Street, south side, between Bedford and Bleecker Streets, adjoining the five-story tenement
No. 14 Morton Street.
About 1915.
Gift of E. M. Jenkks.
(2)
18, lo, 14 Morton Street, south side of eastern section, between Bedford and Bleecker Streets and just east of Seventh Avenue South. This view shows the entire house at 16 Morton Street, which since the date of the old picture has had a doorway cut where two windows used to be. The garage at 18-20 Morton Street is cquite new, probably only three or four years old.
May 19, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
721734f-b.folder: Morton Street & Bedford Street, Manhattan, NY
